questions.text: The third part of the vertebral artery is related to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2

Explanation:

  • The third part of the vertebral artery (V3 segment) runs posterior to the lateral mass of the atlas (C1) and passes through the vertebral groove before turning medially to enter the foramen magnum.
  • Label 2 in the image represents the posterior arch of the atlas, which is where the vertebral artery runs before entering the cranial cavity.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Option C (2).

Vertebral Artery Course & Relations

Vertebral Artery Segment

Course & Relations

V1 (Pre-foraminal)

Arises from subclavian artery, enters C6 transverse foramen.

V2 (Foraminal)

Ascends through transverse foramina (C6 to C1).

V3 (Extracranial/Suboccipital)

Exits C1 transverse foramen, curves over posterior arch (Label 2), turns medially before piercing dura.

V4 (Intracranial)

Enters the skull via foramen magnum, joins contralateral vertebral artery to form basilar artery.

 

4 (Option A): Incorrect – Represents the anterior arch of atlas, which is unrelated to the vertebral artery.

3 (Option B): Incorrect – Identified as the superior articular facet, which articulates with the occipital condyles but is not related to the vertebral artery.

1 (Option D): Incorrect – Corresponds to the spinous process, which is posterior and not related to the vertebral artery course.

questions.text: A patient is unable to abduct his arm. Which of the following root values is likely to be affected
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) C5

Explanation:

  • Arm abduction is mainly controlled by muscles innervated by the axillary nerve from the brachial plexus's posterior cord. It supplies the deltoid muscle, crucial for this action.
  • The axillary nerve is formed from contributions of the C5 and C6 nerve roots, which give rise to its posterior division in the upper trunk of the brachial plexus. Damage at the C5 level can weaken or paralyze the deltoid muscle, affecting arm abduction.

 

 

C4 (Option A): C4 nerve root mainly provides sensation to the upper shoulder, not directly controlling arm abduction. Damage to it wouldn't typically impair arm abduction.

C6 (Option C): C6 nerve root primarily controls elbow flexion and wrist extension. While it aids in initiating arm abduction, isolated damage to C6 wouldn't fully prevent arm abduction.

C7 (Option D): Damage to the C7 nerve root mainly affects elbow and wrist movements, not shoulder motion. It wouldn't usually cause an isolated inability to abduct the arm.

questions.text: The pre-tracheal layer of deep cervical fascia encloses all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sternocleidomastoid

Explanation:

  • The deep cervical fascia is a connective tissue that partitions the neck and supports its structures. The pretracheal layer of the deep cervical fascia surrounds the trachea, esophagus, and thyroid gland in the front of the neck. However, it doesn't cover the sternocleidomastoid muscle, a major neck muscle that sits above it.

cervical fascia" data-author="" data-hash="12350" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" height="329" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/IpCWM4xZFISEhKEBOVZx1746611597.png" width="455" />

 

Oesophagus (Option B):

  • The pretracheal layer of the deep cervical fascia envelops the esophagus, providing a protective covering as it traverses the neck.

 

Sternohyoid (Option C):

  • The pretracheal layer of the deep cervical fascia envelops the sternohyoid muscle, situated beneath the sternocleidomastoid muscle in the front of the neck..

 

Thyroid gland (Option D):

  • The pretracheal layer of the deep cervical fascia encloses the thyroid gland. It forms a sheath around the gland, providing support and protection.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of the nervous system, which of the following nerves can be tested by touching the highlighted structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - IX

  • The Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) provides sensory innervation to the oropharynx, soft palate, and uvula. Touching the uvula stimulates the afferent limb of the gag reflex, which is mediated by CN IX.
  • The efferent response of the gag reflex is carried by the Vagus nerve (CN X), causing contraction of the pharyngeal muscles.

Vagus nerve (Option X): Controls motor innervation of the soft palate and pharynx but does not carry sensory input from the uvula. If damaged, it causes uvula deviation to the opposite side, but it is not responsible for sensation.

Accessory nerve (Option XI): Innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. Has no role in sensation or movement of the uvula.

Hypoglossal nerve (Option XII): Controls tongue muscles, affecting tongue movement. Does not contribute to the gag reflex or uvula sensation.

questions.text: A patient presented with jaw swelling and weight loss. Suspecting a malignancy, the submandibular gland was resected. Which is the most likely nerve to be damaged during submandibular gland resection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Lingual nerve

  • The lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular division (V3) of the trigeminal nerve, runs very close to the submandibular gland and is at high risk of injury during gland resection.

Functions affected if damaged:

  • Loss of general sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • Loss of taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue (as it carries fibres from the chorda tympani nerve, a branch of the facial nerve).
  • Possible decreased salivation (as chorda tympani also carries parasympathetic fibres to the submandibular and sublingual glands).

  • The lingual nerve originates from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve (V3) in the infratemporal fossa.
  • It then descends and moves forward, initially positioned medially to the lateral pterygoid muscle and deep to the ramus of the mandible.
  • As it enters the floor of the mouth, it lies superficial to the hyoglossus muscle and deep to the submandibular duct.
  • The nerve loops under the duct, passing from lateral to medial, before ascending to supply sensory innervation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • This intricate course places the lingual nerve close to the submandibular gland, making it particularly susceptible to injury during surgical procedures in this area.

Nerve to mylohyoid (option A): A branch of the inferior alveolar nerve (V3), it supplies the mylohyoid muscle and anterior belly of the digastric muscle. Damage would affect floor of mouth muscle function, but not tongue sensation or taste.

Inferior alveolar nerve (option B): This nerve runs inside the mandibular canal and supplies sensation to the lower teeth, chin, and lower lip. It is not closely related to the submandibular gland.

Hypoglossal nerve (option D): Supplies motor function to all intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue (except palatoglossus). Injury would cause tongue deviation towards the affected side, but not sensory or taste loss.

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Circumvallate

  • Circumvallate papillae are large, dome-shaped papillae located at the posterior part of the tongue, arranged in a V-shape anterior to the sulcus terminalis. They have deep surrounding trenches (moats) lined by taste buds, which help in taste perception.
  • Von Ebner's glands, which secrete serous fluid to cleanse taste buds, are located at the base of the trenches.

Fungiform papillae (option A): Mushroom-shaped papillae located scattered on the anterior tongue, mainly on the tip and sides. Contain taste buds on their apical surface but lack surrounding trenches.

Filiform papillae (option C): Most numerous, thin, and conical papillae covering most of the tongue's dorsal surface. Do not contain taste buds; instead, they aid in mechanical functions such as food manipulation.

Foliate papillae (option D): Located on the lateral margins of the tongue as vertical folds. Contain numerous taste buds but are less developed in humans.

questions.text: Through which of the following marked sites does COVID 19 spread to the brain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) A

Explanation:

  • COVID-19 can spread to the brain through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone (marked as A in the image).
  • The olfactory nerve (CN I) passes through this region, providing a direct route for SARS-CoV-2 to reach the brain.
  • This explains why anosmia (loss of smell) is one of the early neurological symptoms in COVID-19 patients.
  • The virus can travel along the olfactory nerve fibers to the olfactory bulb, leading to further neurological symptoms.

COVID-19 Neuroinvasion

Route

Mechanism

Clinical Implications

Olfactory Route

Virus enters via nasal mucosa, travels through cribriform plate to the olfactory bulb

Anosmia, encephalopathy

Hematogenous Route

Viral entry through blood-brain barrier via infected endothelial cells

Stroke, brain inflammation

Lymphatic Route

Virus spreads via lymphatics from the nasopharynx

Meningitis-like symptoms

 

D- Foramen Ovale (Option A) – Incorrect: Transmits mandibular nerve (V3) and does not provide a route for viral spread.

C- Clinoid Process (Option B) – Incorrect: Bony projection of the sphenoid bone, not associated with olfactory transmission.

B- Optic Canal (Option C) – Incorrect: Located near the optic canal, which is not the primary route for SARS-CoV-2 entry.

questions.text: A patient after a road traffic accident presents to the emergency room with difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech. Investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region. Which of the following areas should be tested in order to find the nerve which is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) and dysarthria (slurred speech) after a road traffic accident with fractures in the occipitotemporal region.
  • These symptoms suggest injury to the vagus nerve (CN X), which controls motor function of the larynx and pharynx.
  • Option B (2) is correct because this area corresponds to the oropharynx, where CN IX (Glossopharyngeal) and CN X (Vagus) can be tested.
  • Injury to the jugular foramen (through which CN IX, X, and XI pass) can lead to loss of gag reflex, hoarseness, and swallowing difficulty.

Cranial Nerve Involvement in Dysphagia & Dysarthria

Cranial Nerve

Function

Clinical Signs of Injury

Glossopharyngeal (IX)

Sensory to oropharynx, motor to stylopharyngeus

Loss of gag reflex, impaired swallowing

Vagus (X)

Motor to larynx, pharynx, soft palate

Hoarseness, dysphagia, absent gag reflex

Hypoglossal (XII)

Motor to tongue muscles

Tongue deviation to lesion side, slurred speech
  • Testing the oropharynx (Option 2) helps assess Glossopharyngeal and Vagus nerve function since both are responsible for swallowing and speech.

 

1 (Option A) – Incorrect: The cribriform plate is associated with CN I (Olfactory nerve), involved in smell, not speech or swallowing.

3 (Option C) – Incorrect: The tongue is controlled mainly by CN XII (Hypoglossal), which affects tongue movements but not swallowing reflex.

4 (Option D) – Incorrect: The larynx is controlled by CN X, but primary motor function testing for swallowing is done at the oropharynx (Option 2).

questions.text:
Inferior thyroid artery supplies which of the following structures?

1. Thyroid

2. Parathyroid

3. Esophagus

4. Thymus
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1,2,3, and 4

Explanation:

The inferior thyroid artery, a branch of the thyrocervical trunk (from the subclavian artery), supplies multiple structures in the neck and thorax:

  • Thyroid gland (Primary blood supply to the posterior-inferior part).
  • Parathyroid glands (Main arterial supply).
  • Esophagus (Via esophageal branches).
  • Thymus (Via small branches extending into the upper thorax).

Since all four structures receive blood from the inferior thyroid artery, the correct answer is Option A (1,2,3, and 4).

 

Inferior Thyroid Artery

Feature

Details

Origin

Thyrocervical trunk (branch of subclavian artery)

Course

Ascends posterior to the carotid sheath, loops medially toward the thyroid

Branches

Ascending cervical artery (supplies prevertebral muscles)

Esophageal branches (to upper esophagus)

Tracheal branches (to trachea)

Inferior laryngeal artery (to larynx via recurrent laryngeal nerve)

Supplies

Thyroid gland (posterior part)

Parathyroid glands

Esophagus

Thymus

1,2, and 3 (Option B): Incorrect – Excludes thymus, which receives supply from the inferior thyroid artery.

1 and 2 only (Option C): Incorrect – Excludes esophagus and thymus, both of which receive supply from the inferior thyroid artery.

1,2, and 4 only (Option D): Incorrect – Excludes esophagus, which is supplied by esophageal branches of the inferior thyroid artery.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures does not form part of the laryngeal skeleton?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hyoid Bone

Explanation:

  • The hyoid bone is not considered part of the laryngeal skeleton. Instead, it is a U-shaped bone located in the neck region above the larynx. The hyoid bone serves as a point of attachment for various muscles involved in swallowing and speech production. It does not directly contribute to
  • the structure or support of the larynx itself.

 

Larynx- Anatomy

  • The larynx is in front of the hypopharynx, roughly opposite the third to sixth cervical vertebrae.
  • It moves up and down and back and forth during swallowing and speaking.
  • It can also be moved from side to side, which creates a grating feeling known as laryngeal crepitus.
  • In adults, the larynx extends down to the lower border of the C6 vertebra.

 

Type of Cartilage

Paired Cartilage

Unpaired Cartilage

Hyaline Cartilage

(Calcifies with age)

Arytenoid

Thyroid, Cricoid

Elastic Cartilage

Corniculate, Cuneiform

Epiglottis

 

B (Option B): The thyroid cartilage, a key component of the larynx, forms the prominent Adam's apple and helps protect the vocal cords.

C (Option C): The epiglottis, a leaf-shaped cartilage above the larynx, aids in swallowing by covering the glottis and preventing food from entering the airway.

D (Option D): The cricoid cartilage, situated beneath the thyroid cartilage, forms the larynx's base, offering support and stability.

questions.text:
Identify the marked structure



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Superficial temporal artery

 

Explanation:

  • The superficial temporal artery (STA) is a terminal branch of the external carotid artery.
  • It runs superficially over the zygomatic arch, making it a visible and palpable landmark on the lateral aspect of the head.
  • It supplies the scalp, temporalis muscle, and part of the face.
  • It is commonly involved in temporal arteritis (Giant Cell Arteritis), where biopsy of this artery helps in diagnosis.

Superficial Temporal Artery and Its Significance

Feature

Description

Origin

Terminal branch of the external carotid artery

Course

Runs over the zygomatic arch towards the scalp

Branches

Frontal and parietal branches

Supplies

Scalp, temporalis muscle, face

Clinical Relevance

Temporal arteritis, used in microvascular surgery

Posterior auricular artery (Option B): Incorrect because it arises from the external carotid artery and runs behind the ear, supplying the auricle and scalp, not over the temporal region.

Middle meningeal artery (Option C): Incorrect because it is a branch of the maxillary artery and enters the skull through the foramen spinosum, supplying the dura mater, not the scalp.

Occipital artery (Option D): Incorrect because it arises from the external carotid artery and supplies the posterior scalp and occipital region, not the lateral temporal region.

questions.text: A 12-year-old presented with fever and difficulty swallowing. He had swelling in the marked region and was advised to undergo surgery. Post-surgery the gauze continued to soak with blood. Which of the following vessels must have been injured?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Paratonsillar vein

 

Explanation:

The paratonsillar vein is a major venous drainage pathway of the palatine tonsils and is vulnerable to injury during tonsillectomy. Profuse post-tonsillectomy hemorrhage, especially after surgery, commonly results from the rupture of this vein, leading to continuous bleeding.

Vascular Supply of the Tonsils

Vessel

Type

Clinical Relevance

Tonsillar branch of the facial artery

Arterial

Major arterial supply to the tonsils

Ascending pharyngeal artery

Arterial

Secondary supply to the pharynx & tonsils

Paratonsillar vein

Venous

Major drainage vein, commonly injured in tonsillectomy

Retromandibular vein

Venous

Drains the face, not directly involved in tonsillar bleeding

 

Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (Option A): Incorrect because while it supplies the tonsil, arterial bleeding is less common post-tonsillectomy compared to venous bleeding.

Ascending pharyngeal artery (Option B): Incorrect because it primarily supplies the pharynx but is not the major source of post-tonsillectomy hemorrhage.

Retromandibular vein (Option D): Incorrect because it drains the face and has no direct relation to the tonsils.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is an abductor of the vocal cord?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Posterior cricoarytenoid

Explanation:

The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is the only abductor of the vocal cords. It pulls the arytenoid cartilages laterally, opening the glottis and allowing air passage during respiration.

Muscles of the Larynx

Muscle

Action

Function

Posterior cricoarytenoid

Abducts vocal cords

Only abductor, opens airway during inspiration.

Lateral cricoarytenoid

Adducts vocal cords

Closes glottis for phonation.

Thyroarytenoid

Relaxes vocal cords

Lowers pitch of voice.

Vocalis

Tenses vocal cords

Fine control of voice modulation.

Lateral cricoarytenoid (Option A): Incorrect because it adducts the vocal cords, closing the glottis.

Thyroarytenoid (Option C): Incorrect because it relaxes the vocal cords, reducing tension.

Vocalis (Option D): Incorrect because it tenses the vocal cords, adjusting voice pitch.

questions.text: All of the following are paired cartilages except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Thyroid

Explanation:

The thyroid cartilage is an unpaired cartilage of the larynx, forming the Adam’s apple. It is the largest laryngeal cartilage and consists of two laminae fused in the midline. Unlike the other options, which exist as pairs, the thyroid cartilage is singular.

Type

Cartilage

Paired/Unpaired

Function

Unpaired

Thyroid

Unpaired

Forms the laryngeal prominence (Adam’s apple), provides structural support.

Cricoid

Unpaired

Complete ring, supports larynx, attachment site for muscles.

Epiglottis

Unpaired

Leaf-shaped, prevents food from entering the trachea.

Paired

Arytenoid

Paired

Controls vocal cord movement.

Corniculate

Paired

Sits on top of arytenoids, helps with voice modulation.

Cuneiform

Paired

Provides structural support to the laryngeal inlet.

Arytenoid cartilage (Option A): Incorrect because it is paired, playing a key role in vocal cord movement.

Cuneiform cartilage (Option C): Incorrect because it is paired, embedded in the aryepiglottic folds for support.

Corniculate cartilage (Option D): Incorrect because it is paired, sitting atop the arytenoids to assist in voice modulation.

questions.text: Which of the following cartilage do not calcify with age?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Epiglottis

Explanation:

The epiglottis is composed of elastic cartilage, which does not undergo calcification with age. In contrast, cartilages made of hyaline cartilage- such as the thyroid, cricoid, and parts of the arytenoid cartilage- tend to calcify and ossify over time.

Laryngeal Cartilages and Aging Changes

Cartilage

Type

Function

Calcification with Age

Thyroid

Hyaline

Protects vocal cords, supports larynx

Yes, calcifies and ossifies

Cricoid

Hyaline

Provides structural support to the airway

Yes, calcifies and ossifies

Arytenoid

Hyaline (except vocal process, which has elastic cartilage)

Controls vocal cord movement

Yes, except vocal process

Epiglottis

Elastic

Prevents food from entering airway

No, remains flexible

Thyroid cartilage (Option A): incorrect because it is composed of hyaline cartilage, which calcifies and ossifies with age.

Arytenoid cartilage (Option B): incorrect because it has both hyaline and elastic components. The hyaline part calcifies, but the elastic part (vocal process) does not.

Cricoid cartilage (Option D): incorrect because it is made of hyaline cartilage, which undergoes calcification over time.

questions.text: Killian’s dehiscence is seen between?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cricopharyngeus and Thyropharyngeus

Explanation:

  • Killian’s dehiscence is a potential weak area in the posterior pharyngeal wall, located between the cricopharyngeus (inferior part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor) and thyropharyngeus (superior part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor).
  • This site is prone to the formation of Zenker’s diverticulum, a pharyngeal pouch due to increased pressure during swallowing.

Pharyngeal Muscles and Weak Areas

Pharyngeal Muscle

Function

Clinical Relevance

Thyropharyngeus (Superior part of Inferior Constrictor)

Constricts pharynx

Forms upper boundary of Killian's dehiscence

Cricopharyngeus (Inferior part of Inferior Constrictor)

Acts as upper esophageal sphincter

Forms lower boundary of Killian's dehiscence

Killian’s Dehiscence

Weak area between these muscles

Site of Zenker’s diverticulum

 

Palatopharyngeus and Cricopharyngeus (Option A): Incorrect because palatopharyngeus is a longitudinal muscle of the pharynx, unrelated to Killian’s dehiscence.

Thyropharyngeus and Palatopharyngeus (Option B): Incorrect because palatopharyngeus is not involved in this weak area.

Palatopharyngeus and Salpingopharyngeus (Option D): Incorrect as these muscles are involved in pharyngeal elevation, not the formation of Killian’s dehiscence.

questions.text: What is the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Genioglossus

Explanation:

  • The Genioglossus muscle is fan-shaped and extends from the mandible to the tongue.
  • The direction of fibers in the image indicates a broad origin from the mandible and insertion into the tongue.
  • Function: It protrudes the tongue (helps in sticking out the tongue).

Extrinsic Muscles of the Tongue

Muscle

Origin

Insertion

Function

Innervation

Genioglossus

Genial tubercle of mandible

Entire tongue

Protrudes tongue

Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)

Hyoglossus

Hyoid bone

Side of the tongue

Depresses and retracts tongue

Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)

Styloglossus

Styloid process of temporal bone

Side of tongue

Retracts and elevates tongue

Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)

Palatoglossus

Soft palate

Side of tongue

Elevates posterior tongue

Vagus nerve (CN X)

 

Hyoglossus (Option B): Incorrect because it arises from the hyoid bone and functions in tongue depression.

Styloglossus (Option C): Incorrect because it originates from the styloid process and functions in tongue retraction.

Palatoglossus (Option D): Incorrect because it arises from the soft palate and functions in elevating the tongue.

questions.text: The image below shows the cross-section of the trachea. Identify the structure marked.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Trachealis muscle

Explanation:

  • The marked structure is located posteriorly in the trachea, bridging the open ends of the C-shaped tracheal cartilage rings. This is the trachealis muscle, a smooth muscle that allows flexibility during swallowing and coughing.

Tracheal Structure

Structure

Location

Function

Tracheal cartilage

C-shaped hyaline cartilage rings

Keeps the airway open

Trachealis muscle

Posterior, between cartilage ends

Regulates tracheal diameter, aids in forceful expiration

Esophageal submucosal gland

In the esophagus (posterior to trachea)

Produces mucus for lubrication

Perichondrium

Surrounds cartilage

Provides nutrition and support

 

Tracheal cartilage (Option B): Incorrect because the marked structure is soft muscle, whereas cartilage forms the rigid anterior C-shaped rings.

Esophageal submucosal gland (Option C): Incorrect because the structure is within the trachea, not the esophagus.

Perichondrium (Option D): Incorrect because the perichondrium is the fibrous layer covering the tracheal cartilage, not the posterior muscle.

questions.text: Which one of the following cranial nerves is not involved in olfaction ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypoglossal nerve

Explanation: Hypoglossal nerve is a purely a motor nerve supplying muscles of the tongue and has no sensory or olfactory role. It innervates all the tongue muscles (intrinsic and extrinsic) except for the palatoglossus, which receives motor innervation from the vagal nerve (CN X). The muscular/lingual branch is a general somatic efferent (GSE) which controls most tongue actions, including protruding, retracting, depressing the tongue, and changing the tongue’s shape.

Olfaction (sense of smell) is primarily carried by Cranial Nerve I (Olfactory Nerve).

However, cranial nerves V (Trigeminal) (Option D), VII (Facial), IX (Glossopharyngeal) (Option C), and X (Vagus) (Option B) are involved in detecting irritating or pungent odors, contributing to reflex responses like sneezing or coughing.

questions.text: What is the correct nerve supply to the muscles labelled as A and B?

choices.text: A - Nerve to mylohyoid, B- Facial nerve
A - Facial nerve, B- Spinal accessory nerve
A- Facial nerve, B- Mandibular nerve
A - Spinal accessory nerve, B- Mandibular nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - A- Facial nerve, B- Mandibular nerve

Explanation:

  • The labeled structures receive their nerve supply as follows:
  • A (Posterior belly of digastric): Facial nerve
  • B (Anterior belly of digastric): Mandibular nerve

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A - Nerve to mylohyoid, B- Facial nerve: This incorrectly swaps the nerves; the posterior belly is innervated by the facial nerve, not the nerve to mylohyoid.

Option B - A - Facial nerve, B- Spinal accessory nerve: The spinal accessory nerve does not supply the anterior belly of digastric but innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

Option D - A - Spinal accessory nerve, B- Mandibular nerve: The posterior belly is not supplied by the spinal accessory nerve but by the facial nerve.

questions.text: The image below highlights the jugular foramen. Which of the following does NOT pass through this foramen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hypoglossal nerve

Explanation:

  • The jugular foramen, located at the base of the skull, transmits several cranial nerves and venous structures; however, the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) does not pass through it, as it exits the skull via the hypoglossal canal situated medial and anterior to the foramen.

Structures passing through the posterior cranial fossa

Opening

Structures

Foramen Magnum
  • Medulla oblongata
  • Meninges (dura, arachnoid, pia mater)
  • Vertebral arteries and veins
  • Spinal accessory nerve (Spinal root ascends)
  • Spinal arteries

Jugular Foramen
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve (Option C ruled out)
  • Vagus nerve (Option D ruled out)
  • Spinal accessory nerve (Cranial and Spinal root) (Option B ruled out)
  • Internal jugular vein (exits skull here)
  • Sigmoid sinus

Internal Acoustic Meatus
  • Facial nerve
  • Vestibulocochlear nerve
  • Nervus intermedius
  • Labyrinthine arteries and veins

Hypoglossal Canal
  • Hypoglossal nerve (Option A)
  • The meningeal branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery
  • Emissary vein from the basilar plexus

questions.text: After the parotidectomy operation, a patient presents with excessive sweating and redness over the parotid region. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A  - Frey’s Syndrome:

Explanation:

  • Frey’s syndrome (also called gustatory sweating) occurs when a patient sweats and flushes over the parotid (preauricular) region during eating or thinking about food.

Mechanism after parotidectomy:

  • During surgery, the auriculotemporal nerve (a branch of the mandibular nerve, CN V3) is often injured.
  • This nerve carries parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland and sympathetic fibres to sweat glands.
  • After nerve injury, aberrant regeneration occurs:
    • Parasympathetic fibres (originally meant for salivary secretion) regrow and mistakenly connect to sweat glands of the overlying skin.
    • When eating stimulates salivation, these sweat glands are also activated, causing redness and sweating in that region.

Incorrect Options:

  • Horner’s syndrome (Option B): Triad: Ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis (loss of sweating) on the same side of the face due to sympathetic pathway lesion. Here, sweating is increased, not decreased, and there’s no mention of eye signs.
  • Bell’s palsy (Option C): Lower motor neuron facial nerve palsy: unilateral facial muscle weakness, inability to close the eye, drooping mouth. No sweating/redness triggered by eating.
  • Glossopharyngeal neuralgia (Option D): Severe paroxysmal pain in the throat, tonsillar fossa, and ear due to CN IX irritation. Pain, not sweating, is the main feature.

questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with ophthalmoplegia and ptosis. Diagnosis of superior orbital fissure syndrome was confirmed after examination. Which nerves are compressed in this case ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - III, IV, V1, VI

Explanation:

  • Superior orbital fissure syndrome compresses cranial nerves III, IV, V1, and VI, causing ophthalmoplegia and ptosis due to impaired eye movement and sensory loss around the eye.
  • Superior orbital fissure: Triangular gap through which the middle cranial fossa connects with the orbit

Part

Structures Passing Through

Lateral Part
  • Lacrimal nerve (branch of ophthalmic nerve)
  • Frontal nerve (branch of ophthalmic nerve)
  • Trochlear nerve (CN IV)
  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Meningeal branch of lacrimal artery
  • Anastomotic branch of middle meningeal artery (anastomoses with recurrent branch of lacrimal artery)

Middle Part
  • Upper division of oculomotor nerve (CN III)
  • Lower division of oculomotor nerve (CN III)
  • Nasociliary nerve
  • Abducens nerve (CN VI)

Medial Part
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein
  • Sympathetic nerve from plexus around internal carotid artery

 

V2 (maxillary nerve) and II (optic nerve) (Option B, C, D) do not pass through the superior orbital fissure:

  • V2 passes through the foramen rotundum.
  • II passes through the optic canal.

questions.text: The upper part of the uncinate process commonly attaches to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Middle turbinate:

Explanation:

  • The uncinate process is a thin, curved bony structure of the ethmoid bone that extends superiorly and typically attaches to the middle nasal concha (middle turbinate), helping to form part of the lateral nasal wall and the drainage pathway of the frontal sinus.

Components of the Middle Meatus of the Nose:

  • Uncinate Process:
    • Hook-like structure running from anterosuperior to posteroinferior.
    • Forms a gap with the bulla ethmoidalis called the hiatus semilunaris inferior.
    • Divides the lower middle meatus into anterior and posterior fontanelles (membranous areas).
  • Infundibulum:
    • Bounded medially by the uncinate process and laterally by the lamina papyracea.
    • Contains the natural ostium of the maxillary sinus in its lower part.
  • Bulla Ethmoidalis:
    • Ethmoidal cell located behind the uncinate process, forming the posterior boundary of the hiatus semilunaris.
    • May be pneumatized or a solid prominence.
  • Hiatus Semilunaris:
    • Inferior: The gap between the uncinate process and bulla.
    • Superior: The cleft between the bulla and skull base.
  • Ostiomeatal Unit (Complex):
    • Key area where the ostia of the frontal, ethmoidal, and maxillary sinuses drain into the middle meatus.
    • Common drainage pathway for the anterior group of sinuses.

Incorrect Options:

Superior turbinate (Option B): The uncinate process does not attach here; it is located lower than the superior turbinate.

Inferior turbinate (Option C): This is a separate bone and much lower in the nasal cavity, so the uncinate process doesn’t attach to it.

Bulla ethmoidalis (Option D): This is a separate ethmoid air cell located posterior to the uncinate process, not an attachment site.

questions.text: Which is the narrowest part of the adult laryngeal airway?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Glottis:

Explanation:

In adults, the glottis- specifically the rima glottidis, the space between the true vocal cords - is the narrowest part of the laryngeal airway and plays a key role in controlling airflow and voice production.

 

Infant Larynx 

Adult Larynx 

Position

Superiorly placed (C1-C4)

3rd -6th cervical vertebrae (C3-C6)

Epiglottis

Omega-shaped, floppy

Leaf like

Narrowest area

Subglottis

Glottis (Option B)

Submucosal tissue

More abundant

Less abundant

Incorrect Options:

  • Supraglottic region (Option A) includes the structures above the vocal cords (like the epiglottis and false vocal cords), and it is wider than the glottis.
  • Subglottic region (Option C) is located below the vocal cords; it's wider than the glottis in adults but is the narrowest part in children.
  • Trachea (Option D) is significantly wider than the glottis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man came with choking episodes after ingestion of fish bone while eating. The fishbone got impacted at the level of T4 in the esophagus. Which is the most likely site of obstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Arch of aorta

Explanation:

  • The fishbone is impacted at the T4 level, where the aortic arch crosses the esophagus and creates a normal anatomical narrowing, making it the most likely site of obstruction.

Oesophageal Constrictions:

  • Constrictions occur at four main points:

Point of constriction

Distance from Incisors

Description

Vertebral level

Cricopharyngeus Muscle

(Option C ruled out)

6 inches

This first constriction is at the upper esophageal sphincter where the esophagus begins. It is caused by the cricopharyngeus muscle, which plays a role in swallowing.

C6

Aortic Arch

(Option B)

9 inches

The second narrowing occurs where the arch of the aorta crosses the esophagus. The pressure from the aorta causes this indentation.

T4

Left Main Bronchus

(Option A ruled out)

11 inches

Third constriction is where the left bronchus crosses over the esophagus, leading to a narrowing.

T6

Diaphragmatic Hiatus

(Option D ruled out)

15 inches

The final narrowing happens where the esophagus passes through the diaphragm at the esophageal hiatus.

T10

questions.text: Dura when inflamed under the part marked by the arrow gets referred pain at the following site:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Back of the head/neck

Explanation:

The arrow likely points to the posterior cranial fossa, specifically the tentorium cerebelli (a dural fold), as this area is clinically significant for referred pain.

  • The dura mater in the posterior cranial fossa (innervated by the meningeal branches of the upper cervical nerves, particularly C1-C3) refers pain to the occipital region (back of the head) and neck.
  • This is because the sensory innervation of the dura in this region shares spinal cord segments (C1-C3) with cutaneous nerves supplying the occiput and neck, leading to referred pain in these areas.

Referred pain sites:

Vertex (Option B) - Pain from supratentorial dura (innervated by the trigeminal nerve, V1-V3).

Ear (Option C) Middle cranial fossa dura (trigeminal or glossopharyngeal innervation).

Shoulder (Option D) Lower cervical dura (C4-C5), not typical for posterior fossa.

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve passing through the given structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) IV

Explanation:

  • The marked structure is the dorsal aspect of the brainstem, specifically the region of the midbrain, near the inferior colliculus.
  • Cranial Nerve IV (Trochlear Nerve) is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the dorsal aspect of the brainstem.
  • The trochlear nerve decussates (crosses) before exiting, meaning a lesion in one trochlear nucleus affects the contralateral superior oblique muscle.
  • Function: It innervates the superior oblique muscle, aiding in intorsion and depression of the eye in adduction.

 

Trochlear Nerve (CN IV) and its Unique Features

Feature

Details

Origin

Dorsal midbrain, just below the inferior colliculus

Exit Point

Only cranial nerve to exit dorsally

Decussation

Crosses completely before exiting, affecting the contralateral superior oblique muscle

Function

Eye movement (intorsion & depression in adduction)

Lesion Effect

Vertical diplopia (trouble looking down, especially while reading or descending stairs)

 

Cranial Nerve III (Option A): Incorrect because CN III emerges from the ventral midbrain (interpeduncular fossa), not the dorsal brainstem.

Cranial Nerve V (Option B): Incorrect because CN V emerges from the pons, not the dorsal aspect of the brainstem.

Cranial Nerve VI (Option D): Incorrect because CN VI emerges from the pontomedullary junction (ventral side), not dorsally.

questions.text: What is the primary action of the muscle originating from this structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option A) Protracts and depresses the mandible

Explanation

  • The lateral pterygoid muscle plays a unique and crucial role among the muscles of mastication because it is the only one that primarily participates in depressing (Option A) the mandible (opening the mouth).

questions.text: Which of the following structures prevents the upward extension of thyroid swelling through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D) Ligament of berry

Explanation:

  • The ligament of Berry is a fibrous connection between the thyroid gland and the thyroid cartilage. It helps anchor the thyroid gland to the trachea and prevents upward extension of thyroid swelling. This structure is key in maintaining the position of the thyroid gland and preventing its upward displacement.

Pretracheal fascia causes thyroid masses to move with swallowing

  • It encloses the thyroid gland and allows it to move with the trachea during swallowing
  • Berry's ligament also firmly connects the thyroid gland to the trachea, ensuring the gland moves with the trachea during swallowing.
  • This anatomical relationship is useful in physical examinations to distinguish thyroid masses from other cervical masses.

 

Pretracheal fascia (Option A): This is incorrect because the pretracheal fascia surrounds the thyroid gland and the trachea, providing a support layer, but it does not directly prevent the upward extension of thyroid swelling.

Sternothyroid (Option B): This is incorrect because the sternothyroid muscle is involved in depressing the thyroid cartilage and thyroid gland. While it plays a role in movement, it does not prevent upward extension of the thyroid gland.

Thyrohyoid membrane (Option C): This is incorrect because the thyrohyoid membrane connects the thyroid cartilage to the hyoid bone and does not prevent the upward extension of the thyroid gland. Its primary function is related to the movement and positioning of the larynx.

questions.text: The muscle marked by the arrow in the image below is innervated by the :

choices.text: From the dorsal rami of C1

questions.solution:
Correct Option A) Dorsal scapular nerve

Explanation:

  • The levator scapulae muscle is primarily innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve (C5), with additional contributions from C3 and C4 spinal nerves. The dorsal scapular nerve arises from the C5 root of the brachial plexus and also supplies the rhomboid major and minor muscles. Function: Elevates the scapula and assists in downward rotation.

 

Part of brachial plexus

Branches

Roots

Dorsal scapular nerve - C5

Long thoracic nerve - C5 to C7

Trunks

Suprascapular nerve - C5, C6

Nerve to subclavius - C5, C6

Division

None

Cords

Lateral pectoral nerve (Lateral cord: C5-C7)

Upper subscapular nerve (Posterior cord: C5, C6)

Thoracodorsal nerve (Posterior cord: C6-C8)

Lower subscapular nerve (Posterior cord: C5, C6)

Medial pectoral nerve (Medial cord: C8, T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of arm (Medial cord: C8, T1)

Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm (Medial cord: C8, T1)

Terminal branches

Musculocutaneous nerve (Lateral cord, C5-C7)

Axillary nerve (Posterior cord, C5, C6)

Radial nerve (Posterior cord, C5-T1)

Median nerve (Lateral and Medial cords, C5-T1)

Ulnar nerve (Medial cord, C8, T1)

 

Suprascapular nerve (option B): Innervates supraspinatus and infraspinatus, not the levator scapulae. Arises from the upper trunk (C5-C6) of the brachial plexus.

From the dorsal rami of C1 (option C): C1 dorsal ramus contributes to the suboccipital nerve, which innervates suboccipital muscles, not the levator scapulae.

Subscapular nerve (option D): The upper and lower subscapular nerves (from C5-C6) supply the subscapularis and teres major, not the levator scapulae.

questions.text: All of the following nerves are involved in the movement of the eyeball except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A

Explanation:

The optic nerve, also known as cranial nerve II, is primarily responsible for transmitting visual information from the retina to the brain. It is involved in vision and does not directly control the movement of the eyeball.

 

 

Oculomotor nerve (Option B): Cranial nerve III, or the oculomotor nerve, innervates key extraocular muscles, dictating eye movements. It governs the superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, and inferior oblique muscles.

Abducens nerve (Option C): The abducens nerve, or cranial nerve VI, controls the lateral rectus muscle of the eye. It is responsible for the abduction (outward movement) of the eye.
Trochlear nerve (Option D): The trochlear nerve, or cranial nerve IV, innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye. It plays a role in the downward and inward movement of the eye.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Middle meningeal artery

Explanation:

The area marked by the arrow corresponds to the pterion, where several skull bones meet. The middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, runs nearby. It supplies blood to the meninges surrounding the brain and spinal cord, passing through the pterion and branching out to supply surrounding structures.

Pterion:

Located at the anterolateral fontanelle and is formed by the union of

    • Frontal bone
    • Parietal bone
    • Squamous temporal bones &
    • Greater wing of the sphenoid.

  • At birth, this area is filled with a membrane, which typically closes by around 2 months of age, though it can sometimes be delayed until 6 months.
  • The anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery runs beneath the Pterion and Stem of lateral sulcus .
  • Injury to this area can result in extradural or epidural haemorrhage.
  • The pterion is a frequent location for trephination (creating an opening in the skull) during surgical procedures.

Internal carotid artery (Option A): The internal carotid artery is crucial for brain blood supply but doesn't closely pass by the pterion.

Anterior cerebral artery (Option C): The anterior cerebral artery, a branch of the internal carotid artery, provides blood to the frontal lobes and medial brain regions, but it doesn't closely approach the pterion.

Deep temporal artery (Option D): The deep temporal arteries, stemming from the maxillary artery, nourish the temporal head region. Although they are nearby, they don't directly approach the pterion.

questions.text: All of the following are the contents of the carotid sheath except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sympathetic chain

Explanation:

  • The carotid sheath is a fibrous connective tissue structure located in the neck. It contains several important structures, including the carotid artery, internal jugular vein, and 10th cranial nerve (vagus nerve).
  • Sympathetic chain: The sympathetic chain, also known as the sympathetic trunk or sympathetic ganglia, is not a content of the carotid sheath. The sympathetic chain runs alongside the vertebral column and is responsible for carrying sympathetic nerve fibers.

Carotid Sheath: Condensation of the connective tissue around the great vessels of the neck, forming a tubular sheet of fascia.

 

Contents
  • Common carotid artery
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve

Anatomical Details
  • The carotid sheath extends from the upper border of the thyroid cartilage down to the bifurcation of the carotid arteries.
  • The internal jugular vein is lateral to the carotid artery; the vagus nerve is located between and posterior to the vessels.

Anteriorly
  • The carotid sheath is covered by the pretracheal fascia.

Posteriorly
  • The carotid sheath is bordered by the prevertebral fascia.

 

Carotid artery (Option B): The carotid artery, specifically the common carotid artery, is a major blood vessel that supplies blood to the head and neck. It is a content of the carotid sheath.

Internal jugular vein (Option C): The internal jugular vein, running parallel to the carotid artery, drains blood from the brain, face, and neck, and is contained within the carotid sheath.

10th cranial nerve (vagus nerve) (Option D): The vagus nerve, or the 10th cranial nerve, innervates numerous thoracic and abdominal organs. In the neck, it travels within the carotid sheath.

questions.text: Which of the following bony structures is present behind the marked area?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lesser wing of sphenoid

Explanation:

  • The lesser wing of the sphenoid bone is one of the two pairs of wings that extend from the body of the sphenoid bone. It is located at the anterior portion of the sphenoid bone and contributes to the formation of the middle cranial fossa.

Post clivus (Option A): The term "post clivus" is not a specific anatomical structure. The clivus refers to a sloping surface on the occipital bone that forms the posterior part of the cranial base.

Sella turcica (Option C): The sella turcica, a bony depression found on the superior surface of the sphenoid bone, houses the pituitary gland.

Carotid canal (Option D): The carotid canal, a bony canal situated in the petrous portion of the temporal bone, permits the passage of the internal carotid artery.

questions.text: The bleeding shown in the image is usually due to which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Middle meningeal artery

 

Explanation:

The most common cause of an epidural hematoma is the rupture of the middle meningeal artery, which is located beneath the pterion (a vulnerable area on the skull). This rupture typically occurs due to a blunt force trauma to the skull, leading to blood accumulation between the skull and dura mater. This results in the characteristic biconvex (lens-shaped) hematoma seen on imaging.


 

Aspects

Extradural

Subdural

Location

Between the skull bone and endosteal layer of dura mater

Between dura mater and arachnoid mater

Source

Middle meningeal artery

Bridging veins

Suture line

Does not cross the suture line

Crosses the suture line

Classic manifestation

Lucid interval and delayed paralysis that begins in the face and progresses to the lower body

The progress of paralysis is haphazard.

Appearance on CT

‘Biconvex’ shaped hemorrhage

 

‘Crescent’ shaped hemorrhage

 



 

Bridging veins (option A) are responsible for subdural hematomas, not epidural hematomas. These veins, which connect the brain's surface to the dural sinuses, can rupture due to acceleration-deceleration injuries, leading to bleeding between the dura mater and arachnoid mater.

 

Lenticulostriate artery (option C): The lenticulostriate arteries supply the basal ganglia, and their rupture causes intracerebral hemorrhages, not epidural hematomas.

Vertebral artery (option D): The vertebral artery supplies the posterior brain and is associated with subarachnoid hemorrhages or brainstem ischemia, but it is not involved in epidural hematomas.

questions.text:
The posterior end of the marked structure is present at the level of which of the following?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Eustachian tube

 

Explanation:

  • The structure in question is likely the inferior turbinate or the nasal cavity.
  • The posterior end of the inferior nasal meatus, where the inferior turbinate terminates, is near the opening of the Eustachian tube in the nasopharynx.
  • The Eustachian tube connects the middle ear to the nasopharynx, allowing pressure equalization.
  • It is located at the level of the posterior end of the inferior turbinate, around the level of the soft palate.

Eustachian Tube and Its Anatomical Relations

Feature

Description

Location

Connects middle ear to nasopharynx

Opening Level

Posterior to the inferior nasal meatus

Function

Equalizes middle ear pressure with the external environment

Relations

Posterior to the inferior turbinate, anterior to the torus tubarius

Clinical Relevance

Dysfunction can lead to otitis media and barotrauma

Sphenopalatine foramen (Option B): Incorrect because it is located in the posterior part of the nasal cavity, transmitting the sphenopalatine artery and nerves, not related to the posterior end of the marked structure.

Odontoid process (Option C): Incorrect because the odontoid process (dens) is a part of the axis (C2 vertebra), far from the nasal cavity.

Sphenoidal sinus (Option D): Incorrect because the sphenoidal sinus is located superiorly in the nasal cavity, draining into the sphenoethmoidal recess, not at the level of the posterior end of the marked structure.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male recovering from facial nerve palsy complains of food getting stuck between the cheek and teeth while eating. What is the muscle affected in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Buccinator

 

Explanation:

  • The buccinator muscle is responsible for compressing the cheek against the teeth, preventing food from accumulating in the vestibule of the mouth.
  • It is innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII) and is often affected in facial nerve palsy.
  • Damage to this muscle leads to difficulty in controlling food while chewing, causing food to get stuck between the cheek and teeth.
  • The buccinator also helps in blowing air out (whistling) and articulation of speech sounds.

Buccinator Muscle and Its Function

Feature

Description

Location

Forms the muscular layer of the cheek

Origin

Alveolar processes of maxilla and mandible, pterygomandibular raphe

Insertion

Blends with fibers of orbicularis oris

Innervation

Facial nerve (CN VII)

Function

Compresses cheek against teeth, aids in chewing and speech

Clinical Relevance

Dysfunction leads to food trapping in the vestibule, difficulty in blowing air

Levator labii superioris (Option B): Incorrect because this muscle elevates the upper lip, contributing to facial expressions but not affecting food trapping.

Zygomaticus major (Option C): Incorrect because it is a smiling muscle, pulling the angle of the mouth superiorly and laterally, unrelated to chewing.

Orbicularis oris (Option D): Incorrect because it closes and puckers the lips, playing a role in speech and whistling, but not in preventing food accumulation in the cheek.

questions.text: Which of the following is the afferent limb of the corneal reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Trigeminal nerve
 

Explanation:

The corneal reflex (blink reflex) involves two components:

  1. Afferent limb (sensory input):
    • The ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) detects touch or irritation on the cornea and sends sensory signals to the brainstem.
  2. Efferent limb (motor response):
    • The facial nerve (CN VII) activates the orbicularis oculi muscle, causing eyelid closure.

 

Reflex

Afferent Nerve

Efferent Nerve

Accommodation

II (Optic nerve)

III (Oculomotor nerve)

Corneal

V₁ (Ophthalmic, nasociliary branch)

Bilateral VII (Facial nerve, temporal branch - orbicularis oculi)

Cough

X (Vagus nerve)

X (Vagus nerve, also phrenic and spinal nerves)

Gag

IX (Glossopharyngeal nerve)

X (Vagus nerve)

Jaw Jerk

V₃ (Mandibular branch, sensory from masseter)

V₃ (Mandibular branch, motor to masseter)

Lacrimation

V₁ (Ophthalmic branch) (loss of reflex does not preclude emotional tears)

VII (Facial nerve)

Pupillary

II (Optic nerve)

III (Oculomotor nerve)

 

Optic nerve (Option A): Involved in the pupillary light reflex, not the corneal reflex.

Facial nerve (Option B): Acts as the efferent limb, responsible for blinking, not the afferent limb.

Trochlear nerve (Option D): Innervates the superior oblique muscle, which controls eye movement but has no role in the corneal reflex.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pharyngobasilar fascia

 

Explanation:

The arrow in the image points to the pharyngobasilar fascia.

Structures forming the Tonsillar bed

Muscles forming the tonsillar bed
  • Superior Constrictor Muscle
  • Styloglossus Muscle

Structures close to the tonsillar bed (outside the superior constrictor muscle)
  • Facial Artery (Tonsillar Branch): Major blood supply to the tonsils, at risk for haemorrhage during surgery.
  • Paratonsillar Vein: Venous drainage of the tonsil, risk of bleeding during tonsillectomy.
  • Submandibular Salivary Gland
  • Posterior Belly of Digastric Muscle
  • Medial Pterygoid Muscle
  • Mandible
  • Glossopharyngeal Nerve: Provides sensory innervation to the tonsils.

questions.text: A young male presented with weakness in the lower half of the right side of his face, with drooping of the angle of his mouth. He is unable to raise his eyebrows and close his eyes on both sides. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?

choices.text: Infranuclear facial palsy on right side
Supranuclear facial palsy on left side

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Infranuclear facial palsy on right side
 

Explanation:

 

  • Infranuclear facial palsy occurs when there is damage to the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) after it exits the brainstem.
  • This leads to weakness or paralysis of the muscles of facial expression on the same side (right side in this case) of the face.
  • The patient will have difficulty raising the eyebrows, closing the eyes, and drooping of the mouth on the affected side. Both the upper and lower facial muscles are affected.

 

Facial nerve palsy:

 

Feature

Upper Motor Neuron Lesion (Supranuclear)

Lower Motor Neuron Lesion (Infranuclear)

Lesion Location

Motor cortex, connection from motor cortex to facial nucleus in pons

Facial nucleus, anywhere along CN VII

Affected Side

Contralateral

Ipsilateral

Muscles Involved

Lower muscles of facial expression

Upper and lower muscles of facial expression

Forehead Involved?

Spared, due to bilateral UMN innervation

Affected

Other Symptoms

Variable; depends on size of lesion

Incomplete eye closure (dry eyes, corneal ulceration), hyperacusis, loss of taste sensation to anterior tongue

questions.text: A patient presents with the palsy of the face as shown. Which of the following is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 7th nerve palsy

Explanation:

 

The image presents a clinical case of facial palsy. The child's facial asymmetry, particularly the drooping of one side of the face, suggests a lower motor neuron (LMN) facial nerve (CN VII) palsy, commonly known as Bell’s palsy.

 

Bell’s palsy:

Description
  • Most common cause of facial palsy
  • Characterized by idiopathic, LMN facial paralysis of acute onset
  • Most commonly the Labyrinthine segment of facial nerve is involved.
  • Males and females are equally affected.

Aetiology
  • Idiopathic: Most common cause
  • Viral Infection: HSV >> Herpes zoster
  • Vascular Ischemia
  • Hereditary: Positive family history in 6-8%
  • Autoimmune

Risk Factors
  • More common in diabetics (due to angiopathy) and pregnant women (due to fluid retention).

Clinical Features
  • Sudden onset of facial paralysis with inability to close the eye (Bell's phenomenon), asymmetry of the face, epiphora, drooping mouth, and dribbling of saliva.
  • Associated symptoms may include ear pain, noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis), or loss of taste (chorda tympani involvement).

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis is made by excluding other causes of peripheral facial paralysis.

Treatment
  • General: Reassurance, pain relief, eye protection and physiotherapy
  • Medical: Prednisolone 60 mg per day for 5 days then reduced by 10 mg per day (for a total treatment time of 10 days) and 50 mg per day (in two divided doses) for 10 days, Acyclovir (Adult doses)
  • Surgical: Nerve decompression

Prognosis
  • 85%-90% of patients fully recover
  • Incomplete resolution are mainly seen in recurrent/late recovery cases

 

3rd N. Palsy (Option B): Affects the oculomotor nerve (CN III), causing ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and pupil involvement, not facial asymmetry.

 

Erb’s Palsy (Option C): A brachial plexus injury affecting arm movement, not facial muscles.

 

Orbicularis Oculi Palsy (Option D): Would only affect eyelid closure, not the entire face.

questions.text: A singer presents with singing at high pitch. On examination, bowing of the vocal cord is seen on the right side. Which of the following muscles has been compromised?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cricothyroid:

  • The cricothyroid muscle is responsible for tensing and elongating the vocal cords, which is crucial for producing high-pitched sounds. When the cricothyroid muscle is compromised, it can lead to an inability to tense the vocal cords properly, resulting in bowing or a lack of tension, particularly during high-pitched singing. This bowing may be observed on laryngoscopy as a gap between the vocal cords, contributing to a weak or breathy voice.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Posterior cricoarytenoid:

  • The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is responsible for abducting (opening) the vocal cords. If this muscle were compromised, the vocal cords would remain in a partially closed position, leading to difficulty breathing rather than issues with pitch.

Option B - Lateral cricoarytenoid:

  • The lateral cricoarytenoid muscle adducts (closes) the vocal cords. Its impairment would affect the closure of the vocal cords, leading to issues with sound production, but not specifically related to pitch.

Option D - Thyroarytenoid:

  • The thyroarytenoid muscle helps to shorten and relax the vocal cords, lowering the pitch. While it plays a role in vocal cord tension, it is more involved in lower pitches and overall voice modulation rather than the high-pitch tension that the cricothyroid muscle manages.

questions.text: Which muscle movements are related to the Abducens nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lateral rectus

Explanation:

  • The lateral rectus muscle is supplied by the Abducens nerve.

Extraocular muscles

Voluntary muscles

Involuntary muscles
  • Four recti muscles
    • Superior rectus
    • Inferior rectus
    • Medial rectus
    • Lateral rectus

 

  • Two oblique muscles
    • Superior oblique
    • Inferior oblique
  • Levator palpebrae superioris (1)
  • Superior tarsal or Muller's muscle
  • Inferior tarsal
  • Orbitalis.

 

 

Origin, insertion, and nerve supply of extraocular muscles:

 

Origin

Insertion

Nerve supply

(SO4, LR6)

Recti

Common annular tendon or tendinous ring of Zinn.

(all recti have the same origin)

Sclera little posterior to the limbus (corneoscleral junction)

 

The average distance from Limbus is:

  • Superior: 7.7 mm
  • Inferior: 6.5 mm
  • Medial: 5.5 mm
  • Lateral: 6.9 mm
  • Lateral rectus: Abducens nerve
  • Rest all other recti: Oculomotor nerve

(Option B)

 

Superior oblique

The undersurface of the lesser wing of the sphenoid

Into the sclera behind the equator in the posterior superior quadrant of the eyeball.
  • Trochlear nerve

(Option C)

 

Inferior oblique

The orbital surface of the maxilla

Into the sclera behind the equator in the posterior superior quadrant of the eyeball, a little below the superior oblique.
  • Oculomotor nerve

(Option D)

Levator palpebrae superioris

Orbital surface of the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone.

Superior lamella: Anterior surface of the superior tarsus and skin of the upper eyelid.

Inferior lamella: Upper margin of the superior tarsus and the superior conjunctival fornix.

Actions of muscles on the eyeball:

Mnemonic SIN- Superior rectus/ Superior oblique assist in INtorsion
